content.title: Vascular Dementia
content.summary: Cognitive impairment caused by cerebrovascular disease, including strokes and small vessel ischemia, presenting with stepwise decline and focal neurological signs
key_points: Second most common dementia after Alzheimer
Caused by strokes or chronic small vessel ischemia
Stepwise decline often follows discrete vascular events
Neuroimaging shows infarcts or white matter disease
Treatment focuses on vascular risk factor control

statement.text: Cognitive impairment caused by cerebrovascular disease, including strokes and small vessel ischemia, presenting with stepwise decline and focal neurological signs
statement.formal: Vascular Dementia = Clinical presentation + Diagnosis + Treatment

explanation.intuition: Understanding Vascular Dementia is essential for clinical practice.
explanation.key_insight: Key concepts in Vascular Dementia management.
explanation.technical_details: Vascular dementia results from ischemic or hemorrhagic brain injury. Large vessel strokes cause strategic infarct dementia. Small vessel disease causes subcortical ischemic vascular dementia with extensive white matter changes. Mixed pathology with Alzheimer is common.

pathophysiology.mechanism: Vascular dementia results from ischemic or hemorrhagic brain injury. Large vessel strokes cause strategic infarct dementia. Small vessel disease causes subcortical ischemic vascular dementia with extensive white matter changes. Mixed pathology with Alzheimer is common.
etiologies: Vascular risk factors: hypertension, diabetes, smoking, hyperlipidemia

criteria.temporal_relationship: Onset related to stroke or stepwise progression

risk_factor_control.antiplatelet: Aspirin or clopidogrel for secondary prevention

treatment_options.symptomatic: Cholinesterase inhibitors may provide modest benefit
